author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Heart Failure Tied to Increased Cancer Risk, Study Finds
description: People with heart failure may live for many years and should continue to get regular cancer screenings, experts say.
content: People with heart failure may be at increased risk for cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Pithers
title: How to Create a Secret Garden in Your Own Backyard
description: The creative consultant Matilda Goad and the garden designer Butter Wakefield, who’ve fashioned a small oasis at Goad’s London home, share their tips.
content: On the north side of Matilda Goad’s home in London, tucked in a nook between the kitchen and the living room, is a small courtyard paved with granite cobblestones. The narrow yard, flanked on one side by a clematis-strewn fence, has a distinctly rural feel, partly thanks to a salvaged Butler porcelain sink propped against the left-hand wall that, on a bright day in June, is filled with soaking dahlia tubers and foxgloves ready to be planted. A few steps away, above an old zinc bath that contains hydrangea shrubs, their stems hidden by soleirolia, is a porthole window that affords a view through the living room and to the garden at the back of the house. Many a space-strapped Londoner would have opted to build out into this strip of land, known in Britain as a side return, snatching up additional square footage and ramming up against their neighbor’s boundary in the process. Not Goad. “I’m always thinking about creating a slightly unexpected moment,” she says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Ermenegildo Zegna is in a deal to go public.
description: The fashion company will merge with a SPAC, giving it cash to add to its empire.
content: In 1910, Ermenegildo Zegna was founded in the foothills of Northern Italy as a family-run maker of wool fabrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona Awad
title: My Summer of Hitchcock and Cold Cherries
description: The writer Mona Awad on an evening tradition passed down by her mother.
content: Summer brings with it a certain set of rites and rituals — and everyone’s are personal and unique. For our weeklong ode to the season, T has invited writers to share their own. Here, Mona Awad describes the simple pleasures of eating frozen cherries while watching films by Alfred Hitchcock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: Surviving Australian Hotel Quarantine
description: Nothing prepares you for the purgatory of a hotel room that could be anywhere in the world.
content: Two weeks of solitary confinement. No fresh air. An underground network of bartering and information. It sounds like a prison drama or a dystopian sci-fi movie, but it is the reality of Australians repatriating and going through mandated hotel quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: The Olympics and the Jonas Brothers
description: NBC Olympics coverage will begin on Friday with the opening ceremony, and the Jonas Brothers try their hand at Olympic-level athleticism.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 19-25. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: ‘Anti-Sex’ Beds in the Olympic Village? A Social Media Theory Is Soon Debunked
description: The coronavirus has forced a number of social distancing measures at the Summer Games, but the recyclable cardboard beds provided by organizers are not one of them.
content: Competitors arriving at the Tokyo Olympics have discovered something unusual about the beds in the athletes’ village: They’re made of cardboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Mixed signals on England’s ‘Freedom Day’ mean a slow return to the office.
description: The British government lifted nearly all of its pandemic restrictions, but many large companies are approaching the reopening cautiously.
content: LONDON — After 16 long months,  the British government lifted nearly all its pandemic restrictions across England on Monday, including its guidance to work from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canada will reopen its border with the U.S. and hopes to allow others in by early September.
description: The relaxed rules at the border will apply to fully vaccinated travelers.
content: Canada is poised to welcome back fully vaccinated travelers, including Americans, after over a year of strict controls at the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg and Charlie Savage
title: Biden Administration Transfers Its First Detainee From Guantánamo Bay
description: The Biden team picked up where the Obama administration left off with the repatriation of a Moroccan man, reducing the prison population to 39.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday transferred its first detainee out of Guantánamo Bay, repatriating a Moroccan man who had been recommended for discharge from the wartime prison starting in 2016 but nevertheless remained there during the Trump years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 19, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 19, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Robinhood seeks a $35 billion valuation in its I.P.O.
description: The popular stock-trading app said it planned to sell shares at $38 to $42 each.
content: Robinhood disclosed the expected price range for its initial public offering on Monday, putting the popular stock-trading app one step closer to itself trading on the markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: A Girl’s Shooting Death in Washington Leaves a Community on Edge
description: Nyiah Courtney, 6, was riding her scooter on a sidewalk when she was killed, the authorities said. Five adults, including her mother, were wounded.
content: In her short life, Nyiah Courtney, 6, played a lot of roles using her imagination. She was a doctor, a teacher and a babysitter. She went on safaris and rescued animals. She once washed her teacher’s hair in a play sink, cut it and styled it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: In France, angry protests, rising infections and record vaccinations.
description: More than 100,000 people took to the streets over President Emmanuel Macron’s plan for a restrictive “health pass.” But far more booked to be vaccinated.
content: More than 100,000 people took to the streets across France over the weekend to protest President Emmanuel Macron’s tough new vaccination strategy, which will restrict access to restaurants, cafes, movie theaters, long-distance trains and more for the unvaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William E. Spriggs
title: Black Unemployment Matters Just as Much as White Unemployment
description: Because of the Fed, every month from September 1975 to June 1997 the Black unemployment rate was in the double digits.
content: In April 2020, after the labor market took its largest one-month hit in modern history, Black men and women suffered job losses proportionate to those of white women. Still, their losses were far less severe than those of Hispanic men and women. Black workers already had higher unemployment rates, as has always been the case, but their unemployment rates did not skyrocket as much as other groups. In fact, while the Black unemployment rate normally hovers around two times higher than that of whites, the racial disparities in the unemployment rate fell during the height of the coronavirus crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Prince Harry to Write a Memoir
description: Penguin Random House said the book, tentatively coming in 2022, would be “an intimate and heartfelt memoir from one of the most fascinating and influential global figures of our time.”
content: Ever since Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, announced via Instagram that they were leaving the royal family and seeking to establish their financial independence, the couple swiftly began building a media empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: How Versatile Is the Plantain? This Shop Counts the Ways.
description: Kelewele, a new business in the Dekalb Food Market, has a vegan menu where plantains take top billing.
content: In Ghana, spicy fried plantains are called kelewele. And that’s the name that Rachel Laryea, whose family is from Ghana, has given her new food counter in the Dekalb Market Hall. Plantains inform everything from décor to dessert. In addition to spreading the word about the spicy bites, Ms. Laryea created a vegan menu that includes a fried plantain boat topped with Ghanaian bean stew, sweet plantain taco shells with vegetables, and a veggie burger made with sweet plantains and black beans enclosed in a green plantain “bun.” Sweet plantains are the basis for brownies, chocolate chip cookies and soft serve. The sweets, including a plantain dark chocolate brownie mix, are available to ship nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: What Happens if There’s a Covid Outbreak at the Olympics?
description: Kara Swisher finds out why the 2020 Tokyo Games are still on for 2021 and who might be held accountable if they become a superspreader event.
content: People love the Olympics. But this year’s Games, which open on Friday, are plagued with controversial suspensions and public pushback, not to mention the pandemic. How did we get here?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Matt Craig
title: Acceptance and Anger as Los Angeles Mandates Masks Again
description: Monday: As Los Angeles County’s indoor mask requirement took effect, there was eager acceptance and stubborn refusal, mild grumbling and blurted-out outrage.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew LaVallee
title: A Rising Star’s Career Was Cut Short. His Impact Is Just Beginning.
description: Anthony Veasna So died before the release of his first book, “Afterparties,” but his loved ones, mentors and newfound fans are making it a particularly significant debut.
content: Growing up in Stockton, Calif., in what she described as a “very, very, very, very, very loud” Cambodian American family, Samantha Lamb remembers Christmas gatherings during which her younger brother, Anthony Veasna So, quietly sat at his computer while cousins, aunts, uncles and other relatives played games and talked over one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: What Is It About Dating Shows Where Contestants Can’t See Each Other?
description: From “The Dating Game” to “Sexy Beasts,” audiences love to watch daters fall for disguised partners.
content: Falling in love with a partner whose appearance is deceiving is a tale as old as time. In folklore, it’s a motif that crosses hemispheres, exemplified in “Beauty and the Beast”-type tales, in which a woman obliged to live with a beast falls in love with the animal, and later receives the happy surprise that the creature was a handsome prince all along. (The Aarne-Thompson index, which folklorists use to categorize story types, classifies this popular plot as No. 425C.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi and Sharon Chischilly
title: Lost Lives, Lost Culture: The Forgotten History of Indigenous Boarding Schools
description: Thousands of Native American children attended U.S. boarding schools designed to “civilize the savage.” Many died. Many who lived are reclaiming their identity.
content: DURANGO, Colo. — The last day Dzabahe remembers praying in the way of her ancestors was on the morning in the 1950s when she was taken to the boarding school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Ball Gowns Galore! And Other Cannes Film Festival Fashion Statements
description: Forget comfort clothing. Seriously, forget it. The year of the nontraveling sweatpants has come to an end.
content: The Cannes Film Festival that just ended was notable for a number of things (besides simply being the first Cannes Film Festival since 2019): That a female director won the Palme d’Or for the first time since 1993; Jodie Foster’s special award; Adam Driver’s singing in “Annette.” And the fact that it was proof positive, if anyone was in doubt, that the year of the nontraveling sweatpants has well and truly come to a close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Republicans Have Their Own Private Autocracy
description: Loyalty signaling, flattery inflation and the modern G.O.P.
content: I’m a huge believer in the usefulness of social science, especially studies that use comparisons across time and space to shed light on our current situation. So when the political scientist Henry Farrell suggested that I look at his field’s literature on cults of personality, I followed his advice. He recommended one paper in particular, by the New Zealand-based researcher Xavier Márquez; I found it revelatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: These Restaurateurs Want Everyone in America Eating Indian Food
description: Roni Mazumdar and Chintan Pandya, of the restaurants Adda and Dhamaka in New York City, have big plans for fast-casual Indian food.
content: Ten years ago, Roni Mazumdar cautiously added a Bengali dish from his childhood — a beet, carrot, potato and pea cutlet called vegetable chop — to the menu of his restaurant, Masalawala, on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Haiti, Urged by Foreign Powers, Announces New Government
description: Claude Joseph was the country’s leader in the aftermath of President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination. He will hand power to Ariel Henry and join a new unity government intended to keep Haiti stable.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — With foreign powers weighing in, Haitian officials announced a new prime minister on Monday, in an attempt to resolve a caustic leadership struggle in the wake of President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Graham Vick, Director Who Opened Opera’s Doors, Dies at 67
description: The British director was no stranger to the prestige houses, but his calls to make opera more inclusive and available to everyone eventually found their moment.
content: LONDON — Graham Vick, a British opera director who worked at prestigious houses like the Metropolitan Opera and La Scala while also seeking to broaden opera’s appeal by staging works in abandoned rock clubs and former factories and by bringing more diversity to casting, died on Saturday in London. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: How Bad Is the Bootleg Fire? It’s Generating Its Own Weather.
description: Unpredictable winds, fire clouds that spawn lightning, and flames that leap over firebreaks are confounding efforts to fight the blaze, which is sweeping through southern Oregon.
content: A towering cloud of hot air, smoke and moisture that reached airliner heights and spawned lightning. Wind-driven fronts of flame that have stampeded across the landscape, often leapfrogging firebreaks. Even, possibly, a rare fire tornado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Emily Cochrane
title: Lawmakers working on bipartisan infrastructure bill face new obstacles.
description: Senate Republicans warned that they would not move forward with a planned test vote this week on an unfinished bill and negotiators jettisoned a crucial proposal to help pay for it.
content: Lawmakers scrambling to finalize a bipartisan infrastructure bill are facing new obstacles, with key Senate Republicans warning that they would not move forward with a planned test vote this week on an unfinished bill and negotiators jettisoning a crucial proposal to help pay for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Virus Headwinds Hit Wall St. After Months of Smooth Sailing
description: The S&P 500 fell as much as 2 percent, a reflection of concerns about economic growth and new restrictions on travel and tourism.
content: Fear jolted the financial markets on Monday as investors realized that the path to global economic recovery after the pandemic would be anything but straightforward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurence H. Tribe and Stephen I. Vladeck
title: Texas Tries to Upend the Legal System With Its Abortion Law
description: A court battle has begun over the state’s effort to turn its citizenry into an anti-abortion Stasi.
content: Efforts in red states to pass increasingly restrictive limits on abortions have ramped up in the past few years as the composition of the Supreme Court has made it more likely that those laws will be upheld. But a new law in Texas that’s set to go into effect on Sept. 1 is especially worrisome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder and Scott Reyburn
title: Art Meets Luxury Lifestyle at a Gallery’s Sunny New Location
description: Hauser & Wirth inaugurated its latest venture on a small Spanish island. Increasingly, the Swiss mega-gallery doesn’t just sell art. It trades in experiences.
content: MAHÓN, Spain — As the total wealth held by billionaires hits a high of more than $10 trillion, it is also an epic time for luxury lifestyle tourism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Olivia Rodrigo, Fresh Off White House Visit, Stays No. 1 With ‘Sour’
description: The 18-year-old singer earned her fourth week atop the Billboard album chart, following a visit with President Biden.
content: Last week, the singer Olivia Rodrigo walked into the White House with the No. 1 album in the country. This week, having made her pitch to get young people vaccinated, she is still on top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: England’s troubled reopening.
content: An average of almost 45,000 cases of the coronavirus per day were reported in the U.K. in the past week, an increase of 83 percent from the average two weeks ago. Deaths have risen by 141 percent, while England’s chief medical officer warned that hospitalizations were doubling every three weeks and could hit “scary numbers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Democrats Propose a Border Tax Based on Countries’ Greenhouse Gas Emissions
description: Senators introduced a plan on Monday to tax iron, steel and other imports from countries without ambitious climate laws.
content: WASHINGTON — Democratic lawmakers on Monday proposed to raise as much as $16 billion annually by imposing a tax on imports from China and other countries that are not significantly reducing the planet-warming pollution that they produce.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Frozen Land Burns, Siberia Trembles
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 19, 2021.
content: “This is not a phase, this is not a cycle — this is the approach of the end of the world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: 3 Generations, 8 Families: What the Condo Collapse Took From a Church
description: “They were people who you had prayed with.” A congregation and its priest, their faith tested, focus on healing and remembering their lost parishioners.
content: MIAMI BEACH — The Rev. Juan J. Sosa was on his early-morning walk not far from the beach when he heard the wail of sirens. He assumed there had been a traffic accident. But when he walked toward what had been a familiar landmark on his route, he saw only a great void, a gutted tower and a pile of mangled steel and concrete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ex-Student Charged After Putting Hitler Quotation in Yearbook, Police Say
description: The 18-year-old was charged with computer crimes after he used a school database to also alter another yearbook entry to refer to a Boston Marathon bomber, the police said.
content: A former high school student in Connecticut was charged with computer crimes after gaining access to a school database and changing two students’ yearbook quotations, inserting one attributed to Hitler and altering another to mention one of the Boston Marathon bombers, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Mayor Bill de Blasio rejects any new indoor mask mandate amid a case rise in New York.
description: The city’s test positivity rate has recently increased, but it is far from the average of 6 percent hit during the worst period.
content: Though the number of coronavirus cases continues to climb in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday he would not issue an executive order mandating the use of masks indoors, instead doubling down on vaccination as the best line of defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Kurt Westergaard, 86, Dies; His Muhammad Cartoon Sparked Outrage
description: A caricature that many Muslims considered blasphemous prompted a debate over free speech and a massacre at the offices of a Paris magazine.
content: Kurt Westergaard, the Danish cartoonist whose 2005 caricature of the Prophet Muhammad wearing a bomb-shaped turban touched off violent protests by Muslims, prompted a massacre that left 12 people dead at the offices of a French satirical magazine and made him a target of assassins for the rest of his life, died on Wednesday in Copenhagen. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Pair Mariana Velásquez’s recipe for arepas de choclo with a fresh, lemony salad.
content: Good morning. Mariana Velásquez has a smart new cookbook out, “Colombiana: A Rediscovery of Recipes and Rituals from the Soul of Colombia.” Melissa Clark has been cooking from it recently, and brought us an adaptation of Velásquez’s brilliant recipe for arepas de choclo (above), griddled sweet corn cakes. The patties fry into rich, moist, golden disks that are a perfect match for a lemony tomato and avocado salad, and I think that ought to be dinner this evening for as many of us as can manage the task.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: This Grilled Burger Recipe Puts Flavor Over Volume
description: J. Kenji López-Alt unlocks the key to a patty that’s thin and juicy like a smash burger, but with the smoky char of the grill.
content: With the seeming rise in popularity of lacy-edged, thinly smashed hamburgers, many home cooks have turned to converting their backyards into makeshift diners by placing steel griddles or large cast iron pans atop their grills at backyard cookouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Joe Biden Won’t Stop Surprising Us
description: It turns out that the era of big government isn’t over.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, recently you assured me you were enthusiastic about Joe Biden’s big spending initiatives. Am I remembering that right? And are you still on the team?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Hooper
title: I Gave Birth, but My Husband Developed Postpartum Depression
description: Many men struggle with mental health after becoming fathers. But stigma and societal norms keep them from getting help.
content: When I was pregnant with my daughter, my husband and I took a parent prep class in which they talked at length about the signs of maternal postpartum depression. My husband took detailed notes. After all, I had a history of depression and occasionally fell down dark, deep rabbit holes from which only medication and therapy could pull me out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden addresses the economy and pushes for further spending.
description: White House officials and Senate negotiators — including 11 Democrats and 11 Republicans — are working to salvage a deal on infrastructure by identifying a new revenue source.
content: President Biden delivered remarks Monday morning at the White House to press Congress to act on both halves of his economic agenda, claiming momentum from an uptick in job growth over the course of his administration and pushing back on Republican critiques of his multi-trillion-dollar spending plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: The $8 Billion Question: Which Towns Will Cash In on Marijuana?
description: After legalization, municipalities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are deciding whether to permit cannabis businesses to open.
content: Recreational adult use of marijuana is now the law of the land in one of the most crowded corners of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Job-Hunters, Have You Posted Your Résumé on TikTok?
description: Feeling limited by LinkedIn, some Gen Z-ers are now applying for jobs using TikTok résumés. Employers are paying attention.
content: “Calling all recruiters!” Makena Yee, 21, a college student in Seattle, shouted into her camera in a recent TikTok video. “These are the reasons why you should hire me!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Good Riddance, TurboTax. Americans Need a Real ‘Free File’ Program.
description: The company's exit from a federal program that provides free tax-filing software is an opportunity for the I.R.S. to create something better.
content: Intuit, the tax preparation giant, performed a public service last week by announcing its exit from a federal program that let some Americans use a free version of its TurboTax software.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaly Soto
title: Britain’s weather office issues its first-ever extreme heat warning.
description: The warning system is new, an acknowledgment that climate change is warming a nation not known for balmy temperatures.
content: As the heat in London ticked into the mid-80s on Monday afternoon (in Fahrenheit, that is) and Northern Ireland recorded its highest temperature on record, the Met Office — as the national weather service for the United Kingdom is called — issued its first-ever extreme heat warning, covering “a large part of Wales, all of southwest England and parts of southern and central England.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Head of Classic Stage Company to Depart in 2022
description: The Tony Award-winning director John Doyle will leave after six years at the theater — but not before directing two musicals.
content: John Doyle, the artistic director of Classic Stage Company since 2016, announced on Monday that he would step down from the Off Broadway theater next summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Tiffany Hsu
title: Toyota pulls its Olympics TV ads in Japan.
description: The move comes in response to strong opposition to the Games among the Japanese public, with many worrying that the influx of visitors could turn it into a superspreader event.
content: Toyota said on Monday that it had decided against running Olympics-themed television advertisements in Japan, a symbolic vote of no confidence from one of the country’s most influential companies just days before the Games begin amid a national state of emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: On England’s ‘Freedom Day,’ Rising Virus Cases and a Prime Minister in Isolation
description: In a breathtaking gamble, the country has now lifted all but a few pandemic restrictions.
content: “Freedom Day” arrived in England on Monday with its chief architect, Prime Minister Boris Johnson, confined in quarantine, millions of Britons facing the same prospect and untold people more anxious about the risks of liberation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Cats Are Better Than Dogs (at Catching the Coronavirus)
description: Cats and dogs can be infected by the coronavirus — but cats are more susceptible to infection, a new study suggests.
content: In the spring of 2020, as the novel coronavirus infiltrated the Twin Cities, Hinh Ly could not stop thinking about cats and dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Katie Benner
title: Garland tells prosecutors not to seize reporters’ records.
description: The new policy lays out some exceptions and had been expected since last month, when President Biden vowed not to let the department seize reporters’ phone and email records.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland issued a broad ban on Monday on using subpoenas, warrants or court orders to seize reporters’ records from their employers or from communications firms in an effort to uncover their confidential sources in leak investigations, outlining sharp new limits on the practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: An N.H.L. Prospect Is the First Such Player to Announce He’s Gay
description: Luke Prokop, who is under contract with the Nashville Predators, said he was “no longer scared to hide who I am.”
content: Luke Prokop, 19, a prospect with the Nashville Predators, on Monday became the first player with an N.H.L. contract to publicly announce that he is gay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: How Chefs Cook for Kids
description: A new book by Joshua David Stein mines the parenting secrets of the world’s top chefs.
content: Acknowledging the challenges of feeding children, Joshua David Stein, a food writer and parent, introduces “Cooking for Your Kids,” his collection of recipes meant to satisfy children, by saying: “For many parents, myself included, the dinner table can be a battlefield.” So to fill the arsenal he turned to chefs who are also parents. His sources include Sean Brock, Pierre Thiam, Danny Bowien, Elena Arzak, Ana Ros, Jocelyn Guest and Erika Nakamura, Daniel Rose and Marie-Aude Rose, and Suzanne Goin and David Lentz. The recipes run the gamut from simple fruit kebabs by Lee Anne Wong of Koko Head Cafe in Honolulu and a vegetable frittata by Will Goldfarb of Room 4 Dessert on Bali, to an adult-pleasing chicken, leek and tarragon pie from Margot and Fergus Henderson of St. John in London. Each entry has a compelling explanation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: What China Expects From Businesses: Total Surrender
description: Unlike regulators in Europe and the U.S., Beijing is using the guise of antitrust to bring powerful tech companies into line with its priorities.
content: When Pony Ma, head of the Chinese internet powerhouse Tencent, attended a group meeting with Premier Li Keqiang in 2014, he complained that many local governments had banned ride-sharing apps installed on smartphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: As stablecoins explode in popularity, regulators prepare a response.
description: Asset-backed digital currencies have outstripped oversight, but the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve and other regulators hope to change that.
content: Top U.S. financial regulators met on Monday to discuss stablecoins, asset-backed digital currencies that are exploding in popularity so quickly that the government is struggling to keep up — and that economic officials increasingly see as a risk to financial stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christine Hauser
title: Extreme heat bakes the Northern Rockies as wildfires rage in the West.
description: The soaring temperatures have made wildfire season particularly dangerous.
content: A summer of unrelenting heat in the western United States and Canada hit the Northern Rockies this weekend, where temperatures reached the upper 90s and lower 100s with a heat wave that is expected to peak on Monday but ease only slightly through the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in California
description: A bungalow in Alameda, a Spanish-style house in Pasadena and a midcentury-modern home in Twentynine Palms.
content: Alameda, across the bay from San Francisco, is a popular landing spot for those looking for more space and easy access to urban amenities. This house is in West End, a laid-back neighborhood home to Alameda Point, a former naval air station that houses breweries and distilleries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Juliet Macur, Jonathan Abrams and Alexandra Petri
title: A coronavirus cluster overshadows the run-up to the Games as a U.S. gymnast tests positive.
description: Kara Eaker, an 18-year-old alternate on the women’s gymnastics team, began a 10 to 14 day quarantine, her coach said.
content: TOKYO — The opening ceremony is Friday and the first competitions are Wednesday. But organizers of the Tokyo Olympics, delayed one year by the pandemic, are struggling to manage public anxiety about the Games after a cluster of coronavirus cases that threaten to overshadow the festivities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Beta Variant: What Scientists Know
description: The variant can dodge some of the immune system’s defenses, but is still vulnerable to vaccines.
content: England lifted nearly all of its pandemic restrictions on Monday, which some Britons have hailed as “freedom day.” The British government, however, made a notable exception: People traveling to England from France must continue to quarantine upon their arrival, even if they are fully vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends universal masking in schools this fall.
description: The guidance is a split from the C.D.C., which has recommended masks only for the unvaccinated.
content: The American Academy of Pediatrics issued new Covid-19 guidelines for schools on Monday, recommending that everyone over age 2 wear masks this fall, even if they have been vaccinated. Exceptions may be made for those with medical or developmental conditions that complicate mask wearing, the group said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Trail Mix to Remind You of the Classic
description: Shar Trail Mix makes some changes to the classic gorp (dried fruits instead of raisins, more nuts), but it tastes like a throwback snack for summer adventures.
content: Ready to finally hit the great outdoors, take that summer road trip or even a nearby hike? Shar Trail Mix is a terrific throwback to toss into your backpack. Remember simple trail mix or gorp, that loose collection of nuts, raisins or other dried fruit, maybe with pieces of coconut or some chocolate chips? It has it all over many of the new overwrought and gimmicky snack foods. Every bit as crunchy as it sounds, this mix is made from organic ingredients — but no raisins — and has biodegradable paper packaging and offers refills. Some of its profits support local environmental groups through a donation to the Conservation Alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Jett and Jesus Jiménez
title: 5 Texas Democrats who fled their state to stall a voting bill test positive in Washington.
description: The Texas House Democratic Caucus did not name the five lawmakers, but said they were all fully vaccinated.
content: Five of the nearly 60 Texas Democrats who fled Texas last week in an effort to prevent the passage of a restrictive new voting law have tested positive for the coronavirus in Washington, including two cases announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Bill Ackman’s Deal Machine Must Try Again
description: Regulatory pressure forced his special purpose acquisition company to abandon a proposed investment in Universal Music Group.
content: When Bill Ackman’s jumbo-sized SPAC, Pershing Square Tontine Holdings, struck a deal last month to buy a 10 percent stake in Universal Music Group, it did so with a highly complex transaction that took a lot of explaining. Now, pushback from the S.E.C. has forced Ackman to change course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Megan Specia
title: Hundreds Missing in Europe Floods Are Safe, Even as Death Toll Rises
description: As the waters retreat, the region has begun taking stock of the damage and asking questions about how the severe storm could have led to such a significant loss of life.
content: BERLIN — European authorities have revised down the number of people missing as waters receded after devastating flooding in Belgium, Germany, the Netherlands and Switzerland last week, even as the death toll continues to rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Congratulations! It’s a Start-Up.
description: Their friends are having babies. They’re starting companies. So why not throw a “business shower” to celebrate that life change?
content: Sid Singh, 36, was joking recently with a friend that everyone he knew seemed to be having their third baby while he was bringing something entirely different into the world. He had just quit his consulting job to build a financial coaching company. It dawned on him that he could have a baby shower for his new endeavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Weather, Virus, Stocks: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The Biden administration is sending Afghan visa applicants to an Army base in Virginia.
description: The White House has come under heavy pressure to protect Afghan allies who helped the United States and speed up the process of providing them with special immigrant visas.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration plans to evacuate an initial group of Afghans who helped the United States during the 20-year war and who now face reprisals from the Taliban to an Army base in Virginia in the coming days, the State and Defense Departments said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: What You Don’t Know About Food Allergies
description: Pollen-food reactions, adult onset symptoms and cross reactivity are just some of the surprising ways our bodies respond to food.
content: My grandson Tomas first noticed a distressing reaction to hazelnuts at age 8. Whenever he ate Nutella, his mouth and throat felt tingly and swollen, and so this sweet spread was then banned from his diet and the household.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Cecilia Kang
title: ‘Facebook isn’t killing people’: Biden softens his attack over vaccine misinformation.
description: The president said that he wished that Facebook would “do something” about false information about Covid vaccines.
content: After a weekend of rancor between the White House and Facebook, President Biden on Monday softened his forceful criticism of social networks over the spread of misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Pop Music Trolls Grow Up
description: New albums from Doja Cat and Tyler, the Creator place their makers — children of the internet with a taste for friction — in a new light.
content: Over the past month, the Top 5 of the Billboard 200 featured debuts by Tyler, the Creator and Doja Cat, two artists who, early in their careers, sometimes functioned as trolls. They are children of the internet with a taste for friction — Tyler as the leader of the raucous, parent-unsettling Odd Future crew, and Doja as an absurdist with a reckless streak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Accuses China of Hacking Microsoft
description: The Biden administration organized a broad group of allies to condemn Beijing for cyberattacks around the world, but stopped short of taking concrete punitive steps.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration for the first time on Monday accused the Chinese government of breaching Microsoft email systems used by many of the world’s largest companies, governments and military contractors, as the United States rallied a broad group of allies to condemn Beijing for cyberattacks around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: The Failure of China’s Microchip Giant Tests Beijing’s Tech Ambitions
description: Tsinghua Unigroup, a would-be microchip champion, is facing bankruptcy, a setback in China’s quest for semiconductor self-reliance.
content: In 2015, an obscure company run by a real estate mogul woke the world to China’s ambitions in semiconductors, the foundational technology that powers computing. Laden with state funding and political backing, the company made jaws drop with a $23 billion bid to buy the American chip maker Micron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Two New Documentaries Give Caribbean Stories the Depths They Deserve
description: The prismatic “Landfall” and “Stateless” upend typical narratives about the triumph of the human spirit and show us the complexities at play.
content: It is nighttime in Puerto Rico. A dembow beat, the rhythmic foundation of reggaeton, throbs, slicing into the thick air. A man glistens with sweat, an amber light bathing the droplets on his shoulders as he grinds gently against his dance partner. The crowd hollers as a beloved reggaeton anthem echoes in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Officially, the pandemic recession lasted only two months.
description: An economic group concluded that the downturn was limited to March and April 2020, though the pandemic’s impact continues to play out.
content: The pandemic recession is officially over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: England reopened, despite rising cases.
content: Nightclubs across England threw open their doors at midnight as the country ended nearly all of its coronavirus restrictions. But the long-delayed milestone was marred by risk and confusion as Prime Minister Boris Johnson was forced to quarantine because of exposure to the coronavirus, and cases surged to more than 50,000 a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yoani Sánchez
title: The New Generation of Cubans Who Won’t Be Silenced
description: Many in the island had come to believe that the dictatorship would be eternal, that our only options were to flee or to remain silent. But the silence has been broken.
content: HAVANA — The month of July has borne witness to a number of events that have been turning points in Cuba’s history: Fidel Castro’s assault on the Moncada Barracks in July 1953, which ignited the revolution; the execution of the revolutionary general Arnaldo Ochoa that shocked many Cubans in 1989; and the sinking of a tugboat with dozens of people on board heading for Miami in 1994, in what became the climax of the rafters’ exodus. To these historic July dates, we now add the day when we Cubans took back the streets, our streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: It’s Herring Time in Midtown
description: Aquavit celebrates herring with a summer festival that had to be skipped last year because of the pandemic.
content: The season for fresh herring fillets is upon us, and after a pandemic pause last year, Aquavit in Midtown Manhattan has resumed its annual festival of the herrings, this year shipped directly from the Gulf of St. Lawrence and treated to assorted cures and seasonings. Start chilling that bottle of aquavit because this year there are herring kits to go for a festival at home. The package contains fresh herring in seven flavors — including ramp, mustard and spiced — with garnishes, sour cream, cheese, potatoes and crisp bread crackers. The kit is sold on Fridays and Saturdays through July 31 for pickup; limited delivery within a two-mile radius of the restaurant is $5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A wildfire near Lake Tahoe spreads quickly, prompting evacuations.
description: Multiple blazes burning around California have strained crews.
content: A wildfire that has been burning for two weeks just south of Lake Tahoe in California quickly expanded over the weekend, jumping a highway and prompting a wave of evacuations and event cancellations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Capitol rioter given 8-month sentence for trying to stop electoral vote certification.
description: The sentence could serve as an indicator for scores of similar cases.
content: The first person to have pleaded guilty to storming the Capitol on Jan. 6 with the intention of stopping the certification of the Electoral College vote was sentenced on Monday to eight months in prison in what could serve as an indicator for scores of similar cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: How China Transformed Into a Prime Cyber Threat to the U.S.
description: Over the past decade, China reorganized its hacking operations, turning into a sophisticated and mature adversary.
content: Nearly a decade ago, the United States began naming and shaming China for an onslaught of online espionage, the bulk of it conducted using low-level phishing emails against American companies for intellectual property theft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: The Justice Dept. accuses Chinese security officials of a hacking attack seeking data on viruses like Ebola.
description: The announcement came as the White House formally accused the Chinese government of breaching Microsoft email systems.
content: The Justice Department on Monday accused three Chinese state security officials of coordinating a vast hacking campaign to steal sensitive and secret information from government entities, universities and corporations around the world, including research related to autonomous vehicles, genetic-sequencing technology and infectious diseases like the Ebola virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Dolly Parton Tried. But Tennessee Is Squandering a Miracle.
description: I just don’t get it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Dr. Paul Auerbach, Father of Wilderness Medicine, Dies at 70
description: He pioneered a new branch of emergency medicine — when emergency rooms are nowhere to be found — and helped compile the definitive textbook on health care in the wild.
content: Dr. Paul Auerbach, an emergency care physician who pioneered the field of wilderness medicine in the 1980s and then taught ways to heal people injured by the unpredictable, died on June 23 at his home in Los Altos, Calif. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: You’re Missing Microbes. But Is ‘Rewilding’ the Way to Get Them Back?
description: The science behind the idea of restoring the intestinal microbiome to an ancestral state is shaky, skeptics say, and in some cases unethical.
content: As the sun set in Tanzania on a September evening in 2014, Jeff Leach inserted a turkey baster filled with another man’s feces into his rectum and squeezed the bulb. The feces, he said, came from a hunter-gatherer who was a member of the Hadza people and lived nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: The Coach Who Can’t Lose
description: Vlatko Andonovski has not lost a single game as coach of the U.S. women’s soccer team. The Olympics are no time for that to change.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Vlatko Andonovski was 9 years old when he was taught that losing was unacceptable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats Take Stalled Voting Rights Push to Georgia
description: Senators heard testimony from Georgians affected by a restrictive new voting law signed by Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican. Their real aim was to sway a debate in Washington.
content: ATLANTA — Senate Democrats took their faltering push for a federal voting rights law on the road to Georgia on Monday, seeking to make the case for an elections overhaul in Congress from a state at the heart of a national battle with Republicans over access to the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: The Olympics composer resigns after acknowledging that he had bullied classmates with disabilities.
description: In interviews in the 1990s, Keigo Oyamada, known as Cornelius, talked about taunting children with Down syndrome, stripping classmates naked and otherwise abusing them.
content: The composer of music for the Olympics opening and closing ceremonies resigned on Monday after acknowledging that as a student he had bullied his disabled classmates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Joe Kline
title: No Need for Speed
description: At Grants Pass Downs in Oregon, horses come first and women thrive as owners, trainers and jockeys. The approach is good for business, and the community’s soul.
content: GRANTS PASS, Ore. — The safety rail came from the Los Angeles County fairgrounds. The camera towers from another long-gone racetrack in the Golden State. The horse ambulance? Bought in Kentucky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Legal Team Decides Inmates Must Return to Prison After Covid Emergency
description: When the pandemic ends, thousands in home confinement will be recalled unless Congress acts or Biden issues mass commutations.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration legal team has decided that thousands of federal convicts who were released to home confinement to reduce the risk of spreading Covid-19 will be required by law to return to prison a month after the official state of emergency for the pandemic ends, according to officials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Do We Need a Third Covid Shot?
description: The Delta variant has accelerated conversations about introducing booster doses of coronavirus vaccines.
content: The rise of the Delta variant has prompted a thorny question: Do we need a booster dose of the vaccine for Covid-19?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Bill Ackman drops SPAC deal with Universal Music.
description: The chief of Pershing Square said the proposed transaction was drawing concerns from the Securities and Exchange Commission.
content: The billionaire investor Bill Ackman said Monday that he had pulled back from a plan to use his jumbo-size SPAC to purchase a stake in Universal Music Group, the world’s largest record label, after the Securities and Exchange Commission raised concerns about the complex transaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Andean Drink With Long Island Roots
description: Sergio Miranda honed his new bottled chicha business at Fordham and Stony Brook Southampton.
content: Chicha, a centuries-old South American drink made from fermented corn, is often associated with Peru and the Incas. But Sergio Miranda, who is from Colombia and is selling a bottled version, said it was actually popular throughout the entire Andean region beginning in pre-Columbian days. He said his chicha recipe came from his grandmother. It’s pale yellow, cloudy, slightly fizzy, modestly sweetened, sharpened with lime and rounded with cinnamon and cloves for a nicely quenching drink. It has a mere 0.5 percent alcohol and added probiotic yeast. Today’s bottled Peruvian chicha, usually purple and made industrially from purple corn, is often quite sweet. Mr. Miranda started on his chicha project while he was an undergraduate at Fordham University. Eventually he began working with the East End Food Institute, a culinary incubator at Stony Brook Southampton. He uses organic corn grown nearby in Sagaponack, N.Y., and sells his chicha at local farmer’s markets and online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Steven Lee Myers
title: This Train Crash Killed 49 People. It Didn’t Have to Happen.
description: A Times investigation found that systemic failures at a government agency contributed to Taiwan’s worst rail disaster in seven decades.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — It seemed at first like a freak accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Pastrami Egg Rolls, Now Available Nationwide
description: RedFarm and its sibling, Decoy, are now selling frozen dumplings, buns and a Peking duck dinner for four through Goldbelly.
content: For the first time RedFarm, the innovative Chinese restaurant with two locations in Manhattan and one in London, has started shipping food nationwide. It comes frozen with instructions through a QR Code. Among the options are several assortments, including the restaurant’s popular pastrami egg rolls, lamb dumplings and pork buns, and, from its satellite restaurant, Decoy, a Peking duck dinner for four ($139) with a whole sliced duck, pancakes, scallions, cucumbers and three sauces. Be prepared to steam the pancakes and light the oven to warm and crisp the duck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Robinette Kowal
title: Wally Funk Is Defying Gravity and 60 Years of Exclusion From Space
description: Ms. Funk’s trip to space with Jeff Bezos is reason to celebrate. But the launch this week, decades after she was denied the opportunity, also raises questions about whom space is for.
content: Wally Funk is finally going to space. When on Tuesday she crosses that arbitrary altitude that divides the heavens from Earth below, in a rocket built by Jeff Bezos’ company Blue Origin, she’ll be 82, the oldest person ever to go into space. But that is not what makes her so special.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emilienne Malfatto
title: Portraits of Kolkata’s Rickshaw Pullers
description: The dense metropolis is among the only places in India — and one of the few left in the world — where fleets of hand-pulled rickshaws still ply the streets.
content: It was still dark when I met Mohammed near the central market in Kolkata, the capital of the Indian state of West Bengal. He and two other men were piling dozens of enormous jute bags into the carriage of his black-and-red rickshaw — supplies, he said, to be delivered around the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: John P. McMeel, Newspaper Syndicator With a Difference, Dies at 85
description: He and his business partner started in a basement, recruited a Yale student cartoonist named Garry Trudeau, and built the largest company of its kind.
content: John McMeel, a founder of what began as a basement operation in a rented ranch house in Kansas — with a mail drop on Fifth Avenue — and grew into the largest newspaper syndication company in the world, died on July 7 at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Nagourney
title: Ben & Jerry’s to Stop Selling Ice Cream in Israeli Occupied Territories
description: A politically active company just waded into one of the most fraught issues in the world, and the reaction was immediate.
content: Ben & Jerry’s, the ice cream purveyor famous for taking stands on hot-button social issues, announced Monday that it was ending sales in the Israeli-occupied territories — plunging itself into one of the most contentious debates on the international stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Vaccine Persuasion
description: Many vaccine skeptics have changed their minds.
content: When the Kaiser Family Foundation conducted a poll at the start of the year and asked American adults whether they planned to get vaccinated, 23 percent said no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Why Do Prosecutors Reject Sexual Assault Cases?
description: Little has changed in recent years with how accusations of rape are dealt with in New York City, a review of data found.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: Moving Back to Brooklyn and Upgrading
description: After a year in Florida with his parents, he missed New York and he needed a place big enough to launch a vegan cookie business.
content: When Matthew Tanner decided to move back to New York this summer after two years away, he found the hunting process far trickier than it was the last time he looked for a place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: The beds at the Tokyo Olympics are cardboard. Counter to rumors, that’s not a Covid precaution against sex.
description: Competitors arriving at the Tokyo Olympics have discovered something unusual about the beds in the athletes’ village: They’re made of cardboard.
content: Competitors arriving at the Tokyo Olympics have discovered something unusual about the beds in the athletes’ village: They’re made of cardboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Organizing a Union in the Disorganized World of Small Restaurants
description: The stresses of the pandemic and the demands for equity have moved many independent-restaurant workers to start labor-union drives. Will they get results?
content: Worried about returning to work during a pandemic and galvanized by the racial-justice protests throughout their city, 17 cocktail-room employees at Tattersall Distilling in Minneapolis told the owners during a staff meeting in June 2020 that they intended to form a union. They wanted personal protective equipment, overtime pay and antiracism training.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Nicholas Kristof, a Times columnist, is weighing a bid for Oregon governor.
description: Mr. Kristof, a two-time Pulitzer Prize winner known for his coverage of human rights abuses and women’s rights, said friends were trying to recruit him into the race to replace Gov. Kate Brown, a Democrat.
content: Nicholas Kristof, the award-winning columnist for The New York Times, is considering running in the Democratic primary race for governor of Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden praises Jordan’s King Abdullah as a loyal friend in a ‘tough neighborhood.’
description: King Abdullah has been seen by American presidents as a moderate, reliable ally in the Middle East, often playing the role of envoy from the Arab world in Washington.
content: President Biden on Monday praised King Abdullah II of Jordan as a “loyal and decent friend’ as the two leaders met at the White House, a critical visit for a Mideast leader who found himself sidelined under former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Gelinas
title: To Get New York Going, We Have to Address Subway Safety
description: The city cannot simply wait for ridership to go back up, fixing the problem naturally.
content: Roughly 3.9 million people entered Manhattan below 60th Street every weekday in recent years until March of 2020. Most of these people had ridden the subway into town: They flooded up from underground and streamed into offices and restaurants and retail stores, to Broadway theaters and Times Square and the Empire State Building. They made Midtown and Lower Manhattan the anchor of jobs and wealth in the Northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: N.B.A. Pros on the Big Screen: Can These Stars Act?
description: We watched LeBron James, Michael Jordan, Kevin Durant and 11 more basketball greats to see how they rate as actors. We were in for a few surprises.
content: Does every N.B.A. superstar really want to be in movies? You might think so, judging by the long and checkered history of players going Hollywood (not to mention the amount of flopping in today’s game). As the newly released “Space Jam: A New Legacy” takes the booming subgenre of films built on hoops talent into the era of remakes, here’s a guide to the best and worst performances by pro basketball players, starting in the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: White House Dispute Exposes Facebook Blind Spot on Misinformation
description: The company doesn’t know some specifics about how falsehoods about Covid-19 and vaccines for the virus spread on its social network.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — At the start of the pandemic, a group of data scientists at Facebook held a meeting with executives to ask for resources to help measure the prevalence of misinformation about Covid-19 on the social network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: Senators and Biden Aides Struggle to Save Bipartisan Infrastructure Deal
description: A looming deadline and a last-minute need for a new revenue source are complicating a deal that was announced nearly a month ago.
content: WASHINGTON — Congressional negotiators and the Biden administration tried on Monday to salvage a nearly $600 billion bipartisan agreement to invest in roads, water pipes and other physical infrastructure, after Republicans rejected a key component to pay for the plan and resisted Democratic plans for an initial procedural vote on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Indiana University Can Require Students to Get Coronavirus Vaccines
description: A federal judge upheld the school’s mandate. But an appeal is on the way, and the mandates remain divisive across the country.
content: A federal judge upheld Indiana University’s requirement that students and staff members on campus be vaccinated against the coronavirus this fall, but the ruling is unlikely to be the last chapter in the culture wars over vaccine mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Reading the Zoom Tea Leaves
description: Companies are starting to make big bets on how we’ll all behave after the pandemic ends.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Record rain has fallen in parts of New England this month.
description: The downpours have put a damper on the tourism industry as it tries to bounce back from Covid-19.
content: Summer has so far been a washout in much of New England, where rainfall records for July could be broken — and some have already toppled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: 2 Americans Get Prison Over Nissan Executive’s Escape From Japan in a Box
description: The father and son each received a sentence of more than a year and had confessed to helping the executive, Carlos Ghosn, escape.
content: TOKYO — A Japanese court on Monday sentenced two Americans to prison for their role in helping the former Nissan leader Carlos Ghosn skip bail and flee Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Return to Form: Fashion Journalists on Going Back to the Runway
description: After attending shows in person for the first time in more than a year, two industry watchers reflect on the spectacle and the art.
content: The pandemic shook the fashion industry to its core. Stores closed, manufacturing slowed or stopped, companies filed for bankruptcy, and the shows — the grand, crowded celebration of the designs — shifted to virtual moments. But this month in Paris, the haute couture shows were largely back. Celebrities were in the front row. Stilettos clacked. And for the first time in a year and a half, journalists could again experience these creations in the round. Vanessa Friedman, the fashion director and chief fashion critic for The New York Times, and Jessica Testa, a fashion reporter, reflected on the experience of returning to Paris. This interview has been edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Chicago Comedy Institution iO Theater Will Reopen After Sale
description: The storied improv center closed under the financial strain of the pandemic, but a buyer has purchased both the building and the brand.
content: More than a year after it was announced that the Chicago improv mainstay iO Theater was closing permanently because of the financial strain of the pandemic, the theater’s building and brand have been sold to local real estate executives, the institution’s founder said  Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Historic Cherry Lane Theater Sold for $11 Million
description: The Lucille Lortel Theater Foundation, which has managed the 97-year-old theater for the past decade, will take over the building in Greenwich Village.
content: The Cherry Lane Theater, the oldest continuously running Off Broadway theater in New York City, has been sold to the Lucille Lortel Theater Foundation for $11 million, the theater announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The utility PG&E says its equipment may have led to a 30,000-acre wildfire.
description: Blown fuses on a utility pole may have sparked a fire that has burned through 30,000 acres in Northern California, the utility said.
content: Pacific Gas and Electric, California’s largest utility, said on Sunday that blown fuses on one of its utility poles may have sparked a fire that has burned through 30,000 acres in Northern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The U.S. accused China of hacking Microsoft.
content: The formal accusation follows a March cyberattack that targeted Microsoft email systems used by many of the world’s largest companies, governments and military contractors. For the first time, the U.S. also accused China of paying criminal groups to conduct large-scale hackings, including ransomware attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Capitol Rioter Sentenced to 8 Months for Trying to Stop Vote Certification
description: Paul A. Hodgkins was the first person charged with a felony in the attack to be sentenced. His penalty could be a guidepost for scores of similar defendants.
content: The first person to have pleaded guilty to storming the Capitol on Jan. 6 with the intention of stopping the certification of the Electoral College vote was sentenced on Monday to eight months in prison in what could serve as an indicator for scores of similar cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: In Lithuania, Migrants Find Themselves Caught in a Geopolitical Battle
description: The European Union member country says the president of Belarus, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, is encouraging migrants to cross their shared border as revenge for E.U. sanctions.
content: DRUSKININKAI, Lithuania — Migrants from Iraq and Africa have faced rapacious traffickers and perilous land and sea crossings as they tried to make their way to the European Union to seek asylum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Jewish Prayer at Contested Holy Site in Jerusalem Sets Off Alarms
description: Media reports of prayer groups and mixed messages from Israel’s government raised questions about a potentially explosive policy shift.
content: JERUSALEM — Reports of Jewish groups praying at a volatile Jerusalem holy site, in contravention of a longstanding ban, have shined a spotlight on the erosion of a delicate, decades-old arrangement meant to keep the peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Andrew Lloyd Webber Delays ‘Cinderella’ Musical in West End
description: The composer and producer blamed Britain’s coronavirus restrictions for the delay.
content: One day before Andrew Lloyd Webber’s much-anticipated “Cinderella” musical was slated to open in London’s West End, and two days after a cast member tested positive for the coronavirus, the prolific composer and producer announced on Monday that opening night would yet again be delayed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Reprieve
description: In the summer of 2020, This American Life embedded with the staff in the intensive care unit at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit  for months, and tracked how the pandemic had changed them and their city.
content: In the summer of 2020, This American Life embedded with the staff in the intensive care unit at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit  for months, and tracked how the pandemic had changed them and their city.
source.name: The New York Times

description: At a time, during the coronavirus pandemic, when going to the movies was mostly out of the question, an episode to bring the movies to you.

description: Amid a pandemic summer when there were few other places you could go, This American Life heads to the beach.

title: How to Be Alone
description: In space, in the ocean, by ourselves, or with others—we’re all just figuring out how to be apart.

title: The Pitchers Whose Spin Rates Fell Most After a Crackdown on Sticky Substances
description: Strikeouts have decreased and on-base percentage has risen — midseason changes without parallel in decades of baseball in the majors.

title: What You Get for $900,000 in California
description: A bungalow in Alameda, a Spanish-style house in Pasadena and a midcentury-modern home in Twentynine Palms.

author: By The Associated Press
title: U.S. to Send Afghan Visa Applicants to Virginia Military Base
description: The Biden administration said it would evacuate almost 2,500 Afghans who helped the U.S. government during the 20-year war and who now face reprisals from the Taliban to an Army base in Virginia, pending approval of their visas.
content: The Biden administration said it would evacuate almost 2,500 Afghans who helped the U.S. government during the 20-year war and who now face reprisals from the Taliban to an Army base in Virginia, pending approval of their visas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: U.S. Senators Visit Georgia to Promote Voting Rights
description: A group of Senate Democrats traveled to Atlanta on Monday to speak to voters who have faced challenges casting their ballots, in an effort to highlight the need for new federal voting rights protections.
content: A group of Senate Democrats traveled to Atlanta on Monday to speak to voters who have faced challenges casting their ballots, in an effort to highlight the need for new federal voting rights protections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nyc Mayor's Office, Via Youtube
title: De Blasio Says He Won’t Mandate Masks to Fight Delta Variant
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said he would not support additional indoor mask requirements as the Delta variant fuels rising coronavirus cases in the city, and doubled down on vaccinations as the best defense.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said he would not support additional indoor mask requirements as the Delta variant fuels rising coronavirus cases in the city, and doubled down on vaccinations as the best defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: ‘We Will Always Be There for Jordan,’ Biden Says
description: President Biden hosted King Abdullah II of Jordan at the White House on Monday, the first Arab leader to visit during his presidency, in a sign of strengthening ties after a rocky relationship with the Trump administration.
content: President Biden hosted King Abdullah II of Jordan at the White House on Monday, the first Arab leader to visit during his presidency, in a sign of strengthening ties after a rocky relationship with the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: London Nightclubs Ring in ‘Freedom Day’ as Virus Cases Rise
description: Crowds packed onto dance floors after England lifted most coronavirus restrictions on social contact and ended its mask mandate, despite surging cases.
content: Crowds packed onto dance floors after England lifted most coronavirus restrictions on social contact and ended its mask mandate, despite surging cases.
